A servo motor provides positional feedback. You can have dc servo motors. You can have stepper motors that use a home sensor and pulse counts to reach a position but they are not servoes. But a servo motor, be it dc, stepper, etc has a feedback loop like a potentimeter or an encoder to actually tell the driver the real time position of the motor.

Boat, Rock, and water riddle is really bad to visualize. this assumes the boat is heavy. I had a less clean solution for the sticks problem: First, burn one stick from both ends = 30 minutes. Then, break the other stick at its approximate middle. You now have two smaller sticks, i.e. four ends. Light all four ends. Since the stick takes 1 hour to burn if lit in one spot, it will now burn four times as fast, thus burning in 60/4 = 15 minutes, bringing the total to 45 minutes. If one mini-stick burns out before the other, break the remaining stick in half and light all four ends of the resultant halves. As long as the stick is lit continuously (assuming breaking the stick and relighting can be done instantaneously) in four locations, the second stick will burn up completely by the end of 45 minutes.

3. You light the other one from both sides again and track it’s length while it is burning.
4.You stop when the stick has bunt half it’s size (15 min)
5.There you have your 45 mins .

But I have to ask Diana, how did you not instantly know bit vs byte? I thought you were working as a programmer? Granted, it's usually just ints everywhere (not even specifically 32 bit ones but ints dependent on the underlying architecture the code is compiled for), but still there's the occasional necessity for bytes (bits are always in use, but they're most often called bools so fair enough on not connecting that dot) which also equate to 256 bits (0-255) which, for example, constitutes colours; usually you have an (a)rgb definition of a colour with the channels of it in separate byte variables.
I'm not slagging or something, I'm just curious how this is not something you instantly recognise?

Making a claw machine that has the strength and precision to win every time would be a terrible idea. You would have to fill it with prizes that are worth less than the money it takes to play in order to make a profit. Of course that profit would have to go to covering the costs of the machine itself before it can really be profit. When you introduce the possibility of failing you increase the profit which allows you to put better prizes inside the machine. Failure also is what makes it a game of skill/luck. Without that aspect of it then it'd be about as exciting and unpredictable as a vending machine giving you a soda.

I can show you examples of servo systems in which the motors are either AC or DC. The difference between the two systems (servo motors and DC motors) is that you can control how many times a “servo” motor rotates and to what position it will stop, thus having accurate control over the output. The example picture you used is a DC motor because it has permanent magnet poles. If you removed the magnets and added coils for each pole that same motor would run on either AC or DC.

The other example picture is not very clear but I would guess those are “Stepper” motors with gear reduction units. Those stepper motors also run on DC.

The candle question was pretty tricky for me. I thought about it for a while, and came up with a different solution.

You float one candle in some sort of boat inside of a sufficiently large vertical cylinder (of similar density to the water) that is closed at the top. The cylinder is also floating. You mark the water level on the side of the cylinder. You light the candle, and burn it all the way through, then mark the new higher water level on the side of the cylinder. Lastly, you can simply measure 3/4 of the way up between the two lines, and mark that point as 45min. Then let more air (of the same oxygen concentration) into the cylinder, such that the water level returns to the first, lower mark. Burn the second candle in that cylinder and once the water level reaches the 45min mark, it's been 45 minutes!

Obviously, this solution is more complicated, and takes a lot more time and resources to set up, but it should work, and has the advantage that you an effectively measure any amount of time, up to an hour, theoretically. There are also some oversights here that reduce the accuracy of this method, but those variations can be minimized with some clever engineering.

Considering this video is intended to allow people to take away some knowledge regarding the questions , I must inform you that your understanding of DC vs. Servo motors is incorrect. More accurately, the question is incorrect.  A servo motor can still be a DC motor. The majority of servo motors are in fact DC motors.  The requirement for a DC (or any type) motor to be a servo is some form of feedback to provide positional information. This can be as simple as an encoder, or a resolver , or some other means to tell where the shaft, or something it is connected to is positioned. Either absolutely, or relatively.   A servo motor can be any type of motor. DC brushed, DC brushless, stepper, AC, etc..  The more appropriate question would be "What is a servo motor" or "When does a DC motor become a servo motor".   Actually, the motor itself never becomes a "servo" motor at all.  Its the system as a whole that is a "servo" , not the motor.  It is just referred to as such ,as motors with positional feedback are typically used in servo systems , and should be thought of more as "Motor used in a servo system"

More nice little (if very pedantic) bit/byte facts: If you want to specifically refer to 8 bits, use the word "octet". Solution: Light both ends of one stick, and one end of the other. The one lit on both ends will be burnt up after 30 minutes, even with the non-uniform burn rate. At that point, the other stick will have burnt for 30 minutes, and have 30 minutes of burn time left. Light the unlit end of that, and voila; 30min+15min=45min

I have an alternate answer to the stick problem.
You have two sticks:
- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -

Because they both burn at the same varied rate, if you burn them from opposite ends, when they meet it will be half an hour. 30 minutes on both sides:
- - - - x x x x x x x
x x x - - - - - - - - -

Now 30 minutes has passed. Now you can use the same idea of burning sides meeting together to cut the remaining 30 minutes of the bottom stick in half again. Just start burning the right side and continue burning the left:
x x x - - - - - - - - x

When they meet, it will be 30 + 15 = 45 minutes. (xx) = spot where they meet:
x x x x x (xx) x x

That's my solution to timing 45 minutes.

ANSWER TO THE BURNING LOGS PROBLEM  - We will first lie them parallel, toiching each other. Now will burn one log from say left end . when the burning end comes in the same perp. line as the line which passes through centre of unburned log. Then we can say 30 minutes has passed. Simultaneously, we will burn the next log from the opposite end. So when the burning ends of both come again in a same perpendicular line, the second long has burned 1/4th of its length while the first log has burned 1/2 of 1/2 of it, means 1/4 of the total length. So in the second part, the both the logs has burned for 1 hour x 1/4 =15 minutes. As we have already had 30 minutes counted earlier. Then the total time = 30 +15 =45 minutes

The Boat Riddle, Answer(s):
The water could go Down, Or stay the Same .

1. Like Dianne said, If a 100tonne stone was in the boat, it would sink a small boat faaar, Displacing Alot of Water... Toss the stone out, the Boat Rapidly Rises, The water rushes in to fill the gap, the water level drops. then when the stone finally falls into the water, it will then cause the water to rise. But if that stonne was tiny like a pebble , it barley raises the water. The water still lower than before.

2. Unlike Dianne said, if the object was 1 weight, and 1 volume, it would displace evenly. Having it in the boat would drop the boat by 1 weight, enough to displace 1 volume of water. Throwing it out would let the boat rise 1 weight worth, and the water would fill in the gap (of 1). Now when the object reaches the water, it sinks 1 weight, floating below the surface, and displaces 1 volume of water, the water now rises 1 unit. The water level stayed the same.

3. If the object is lightweight but huge, it only displaces it's weight worth, either in boat or when floating. Displacement is equal.

4. Up?? I dunno with certainty about that. A Day Goes by..... Oh wait. The water rises when the object is picked up. And lets not forget about bobbing.
